 It is an interesting thought to consider whether we can equate the right to vote in Oz with the RKBA in America. 
 
 In America we tend to look at rights in two ways. Some rights we look on as freedoms to choose whether or not to do something (like speech, press, assembly, religion, RKBA, or the right to vote, for example). Other rights we look upon as freedoms which prevent the government from doing things to us (unreasonable search and seizure, forcing us to incriminate ourselves, quartering soldiers in our homes, or imposing cruel and unusual punishments, for example). 
 
 The Australian voting issue appears to take a slightly different view. You have the right to vote, but as a condition of citizenship the government has chosen to impose an affirmative duty-an obligation, if you will-to exercise that right. 
 
 The more interesting question is where does the power for the right originate? Is it, like the right of free speech in America, a right declared to be inherently held by the people which the government is required by the language of its charter to recognize and accept? Or is it a right which the government through its charter grants to its citizens? 
 
 If it is the latter, then the right is "owned" by the government, and of course the government can make the grant of the right conditional on any terms it pleases-like an obligation to either exercise it or justify the failure to do so to the satisfaction of a government functionary. But if it is viewed as a right inherently held by the people which the government is required to recognize and protect, then it becomes a more difficult task to justify the government's desire to fine those who fail to exercise it. 
 
 In any event, the Australian government apparently feels that the right is so important to its ability to function properly that it punishes you for refusing to fully play your part in the democratic process. You could even go so far as to call it a deadbeat citizen tax. Whether you approve of such measures is a matter of opinion. I for one do not. 
 
 It is not analogous, however, to the RKBA and the potential duty of militia service. To equate the two requires a belief that the RKBA is limited to militia service, which is not the case. The RKBA is only tied to militia service in the minds of those who choose to read the 2nd. Amendment in conflict with itself-by using the militia preamble as a limit on the operable clause. After all, they co-exist in the same amendment, don't they-or so the argument goes. But here is why I believe the militia preamble was included in the 2nd. Amendment.... 
 
 We first have to understand that the militia preamble is nothing more than a statement of a policy goal. The fear was that Congress would raise a standing army, which was universally believed to be a potential engine of despotism. The preferred policy, as expressed in the 2nd. Amendment, was to avoid standing armies wherever possible and instead rely on militias for security. One of the best statements of this policy goal can be seen here: 
 
 "It has been asserted by the most respectable writers upon government, that a well-regulated militia, composed of the yeomanry of the country, have ever been considered as the bulwark of a free people. Tyrants have never placed any confidence on a militia composed of freemen." John DeWitt, The Anti-Federalist Papers, p. 75 (M. Borden ed. 1965)
 
 This was the policy goal captured in the militia preamble. It is for this reason the amendment reads "A well regulated militia being necessary to the security of a free State." That is, a state in which men live freely without fear of a domestic tyrant. 
 
 Now here in my opinion is why this policy goal was included in the amendment-a natural offshoot of the broader individual RKBA was its ability to help the citizens preserve an effective militia. Remember that Congress not only had the power to raise a standing federal army-it was also granted the authority to arm and equip the militias. The fear was that Congress could effectively disarm the militias by not only refusing to exercise that power to arm them but by also claiming the states were forbidden to do so by the supremacy clause. If there were not an individual RKBA, then no alternative source of arms would exist, and in such an instance the states would be powerless to organize citizens to effectively resist a federal tyrant wielding a federal army. Patrick Henry in particular saw this as a problem:
 
 "Is it necessary for your liberty, that you should abandon those great rights by the adoption of this system?. . . Will the abandonment of your most sacred rights tend to the security of your liberty?. . . .I am fearful I have lived long enough to become an old fashioned fellow: Perhaps an invincible attachment to the dearest rights of man, may, in these refined enlightened days, be deemed old fashioned: If so, I am contented to be so. . . . Guard with jealous attention the public liberty. Suspect everyone who approaches that jewel. Unfortunately, nothing will preserve it, but downright force: Whenever you give up that force, you are inevitably ruined. . . .
 
 My great objection to this Government is, that it does not leave us the means of defending our rights; or, of waging war against tyrants. . . .
 
 The Honorable Gentleman who presides, told us, that to prevent abuses in our Government, we will assemble in Convention, recall our delegated powers, and punish our servants for abusing the trust reposed in them. Oh, Sir, we should have fine times indeed, if to punish tyrants, it were only sufficient to assemble the people. Your arms wherewith you could defend yourselves, are gone. . . . Did you ever read of any revolution in any nation, brought about by the punishment of those in power, inflicted by those who had no power at all? You read of a riot act in a country [ England ] which is called one of the freest in the world, where a few neighbors cannot assemble without the risk of being shot by hired soldiery, the engines of despotism. We may see such an act in America . A standing army we shall have also, to execute the execrable commands of tyranny: And how are you to punish them? Will you order them to be punished? Who shall obey these orders? Will your Mace-bearer be a match for a disciplined regiment? In what situation are we to be? . . . .What resistance could be made? The attempt would be madness." Patrick Henry, Speeches of June 5 and 7, 1788, before the Virginia Ratifying Convention, reprinted in The Anti-Federalist Papers and the Constitutional Convention Debates, pages 199-216, Mentor Books, 1986, edited by Ralph Ketchum.
 
 The answer to Henry's complaint was simple. Either draft an Amendment which specifically granted the states the power to concurrently arm their militias free from congressional interference, or recognize an individual RKBA which the federal government could not deny. America clearly chose the latter course of recognizing a broader, separate individual right which-as a benefit of its existence-could in turn provide the alternative source for arming a militia should the need arise. See, for example, the recognition of this in U.S. v. Miller: "that ordinarily when called for service these men were expected to appear bearing arms supplied by themselves and of a kind in common use at the time."
 
 See also how Tench Coxe described the Amendment: 
 
 "As civil rulers, not having their duty to the people duly before them, may attempt to tyrannize, and as the military forces which must be occasionally raised to defend our country, might pervert their power to the injury of their fellow citizens, the people are confirmed by the article in their right to keep and bear private arms." Tench Coxe, discussing the purpose of the Second Amendment in his "Remarks on the First Part of the Amendments to the Federal Constitution," published under the pseudonym, "A Pennsylvanian" in the Philadelphia Federal Gazette, June 18, 1789 at 2 Col. 1.
 
 Do you see how the broader individual right exists independently of a smaller duty to provide militia service if called upon-and is linked only coincidentally because its existence helps provide a ready source of armed men in an emergency? No where do you see even the slightest imposition of a suggestion that the right is limited by the militia preamble. In Oz, for example, it appears that having a duty to vote is a prerequisite to having the right to vote. But in America performing a militia duty has never been deemed a prerequisite of exercising the RKBA. This is why no SCOTUS decision has ever held that one must actually be performing the duty of militia service before he can mount a claim of infringement of his right-because the right is not limited by the smaller duty it could help the citizen perform. 
 
 So I guess I don't see how we can fairly equate voting in Oz with the RKBA in America without turning the amendment on its head and reading it in conflict with itself. And to me it appears beyond the common sense of mankind for someone to believe that this militia policy preamble was intended to restrict the RKBA to it as a sole justification for existence (and as a defined boundary of the right)-particularly when they offer not the slightest evidence in support of this claim other than the strength of their desire to have the tail wag the dog.

I believe that our founding fathers frequently used preambles as declarations of strongly held beliefs or principles. Here is one example from the first American Constitution, the Constitution of Virginia (June 6, 1776):
 
 “That religion, or the duty which we owe to our Creator, and the manner of discharging it, can be directed only by reason and conviction, not by force or violence; and therefore all men are equally entitled to the free exercise of religion, according to the dictates of conscience; and that it is the mutual duty of all to practice Christian forbearance, love, and charity towards each other.”
 
 Here is how I break this clause down: You start with a preamble, a statement of principle--“That religion, or the duty which we owe to our Creator, and the manner of discharging it, can be directed only by reason and conviction, not by force or violence”—followed by the actual operable language which expresses the right--“and therefore all men are equally entitled to the free exercise of religion, according to the dictates of conscience”—followed by another, closing statement of principle--“and that it is the mutual duty of all to practice Christian forbearance, love, and charity towards each other.”
 
 No one suggests that this preamble was intended to limit the right it helps introduce.
 
 Here is another example, this time from the Constitution of North Carolina (December 14, 1776):
 
 “That retrospective laws, punishing facts committed before the existence of such laws, and by them only declared criminal, are oppressive, unjust, and incompatible with liberty; wherefore no ex post facto law ought to be made.”
 
 From this provision we see another use of a preamble to state a principle—“That retrospective laws, punishing facts committed before the existence of such laws, and by them only declared criminal, are oppressive, unjust, and incompatible with liberty”—followed by the operable language of the right—“wherefore no ex post facto law ought to be made.”
 
 And again no one suggests that this preamble was intended to do anything other than introduce the right.
 
 Preambles like this were in fact very common. I have argued before that the militia clause of the 2nd. Amendment is nothing more than another of these statements of principle:
 
 “A well regulated militia being necessary to the security of a free State”(emphasis added)
 
 I still believe this is nothing more than a restatement of a universally held principle that I quoted before:
 
 “It has been asserted by the most respectable writers upon government, that a well-regulated militia, composed of the yeomanry of the country, have ever been considered as the bulwark of a free people. Tyrants have never placed any confidence on a militia composed of freemen.” John DeWitt, The Anti-Federalist Papers, p. 75 (M. Borden ed. 1965) 
 
 I have found it was also espoused by Patrick Henry: 
 
 “[T]hat a well regulated militia, composed of gentlemen and yeomen, is the natural strength and only security of a free government.” Speech of Patrick Henry in R. Meade's Patrick Henry, p. 28 (1969).
 
 But it was not only private citizens who felt the need to make this statement of principle. It was included in many of the state constitutions. Here are a few examples:
 
 CONSTITUTION OF VIRGINIA (June 6, 1776)
 
 That a well-regulated militia, composed of the body of the people, trained to arms, is the proper, natural, and safe defense of a free state; that standing armies, in time of peace, should be avoided, as dangerous to liberty; and that in all cases the military should be under strict subordination to, and governed by, the civil power.
 
 DELAWARE DECLARATION OF RIGHTS (September 11, 1776)
 
 That a well-regulated militia is the proper, natural and safe defense of a free government.
 That standing armies are dangerous to liberty, and ought not to be raised or kept up without the consent of the legislature.
 
 CONSTITUTION OF MARYLAND (November 3, 1776)
 
 That a well-regulated militia is the proper and natural defense of a free government.
 That standing armies are dangerous to liberty, and ought not to be raised or kept up, without consent of the legislature.
 
 CONSTITUTION OF NEW HAMPSHIRE (June 2, 1784)
 
 A well-regulated militia is the proper, natural, and safe defense of a state.
 Standing armies are dangerous to liberty, and ought not to be raised or kept up without the consent of the legislature.
 
 You can see from this that all Madison did was cut this statement of a widely held belief from the state constitutions and paste in into the BoR as a preamble for the 2nd. Amendment. V. Drafting of the Federal Bill of Rights 
 When James Madison found himself cast in the unlikely role of father of the national bill of rights,[234] he was not forced to write upon a clean slate. His first step was to obtain a pamphlet which conveniently listed all state proposals, from the Pennsylvania minority onward.[235] The problem became one of editing; out of hundreds of proposals, many redundant and some questionable, a hard core of usable proposals had to be selected. The barriers to be surmounted required discarding all controversial proposals. As he informed Jefferson, "every thing of a controvertible nature that might endanger the concurrence of two-thirds of each House and three quarters of the States was studiously avoided."[236] After excluding the controversial propositions, Madison still had to single out the most desirable proposal, and then (where several different proposals had been made to a single end) select the specific terms of the guarantee. Finally, he had to decide how to assemble and group the rights into a number of amendments. The last task was to a certain extent governed by Madison's plan (which had been retained in committee) to (p.54)interweave the amendments into the text of the constitution, in the manner of a modern "pocket part."[237]
 
 Madison's decision to include a right to arms in his federal bill of rights is hardly surprising.
